https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

| `Mathlib.Algebra.Order.Hom.Ultra`|949|
| `Mathlib.Data.Real.IsNonarchimedean`|1212|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

</details>

Thanks :tada:

bors merge

Build failed (retrying...):
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11145027501/job/30973641493)

Build failed:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11146130290/job/30977345072)
Thanks! @jcommelin I think this is ready to go again, I think you can bors-ify it again.

I'm afraid that there has been some duplication going on here: many of the lemmas in this PR are essentially identical to lemmas that have been independently added by @pechersky in #14768, see `Mathlib.Analysis.Normed.Group.Ultra`. 

Yakov's spellings are slightly different, because the assumptions are given as `[Seminormed{Add}Group X] [IsUltrametricDist X]` rather than `[IsNonarchimedean (norm : X \to \RR)]`. I think we should try to standardize on one spelling rather than doing everything twice.

Muddying the waters further, we also seem to have `NonarchimedeanHomClass` and various variants of it. @mariainesdff, since you seem to be the author of those classes and also of this PR, can you comment on how they relate to each other?

> I'm afraid that there has been some duplication going on here: many of the lemmas in this PR are essentially identical to lemmas that have been independently added by @pechersky in #14768, see `Mathlib.Analysis.Normed.Group.Ultra`.
> 
> Yakov's spellings are slightly different, because the assumptions are given as `[Seminormed{Add}Group X] [IsUltrametricDist X]` rather than `[IsNonarchimedean (norm : X \to \RR)]`. I think we should try to standardize on one spelling rather than doing everything twice.

[IsUltrametricDist](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/MetricSpace/Ultra/Basic.html#IsUltrametricDist) is not enough for my purposes since it assumes that you have some canonical distance function (which in lemmas like [IsUltrametricDist.norm_add_le_max](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Normed/Group/Ultra.html#IsUltrametricDist.norm_add_le_max) would be the one induced by a bundled [SeminormedAddGroup](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Normed/Group/Basic.html#SeminormedAddGroup) structure on your type).

However, I want to be able to make the statement that _a_ (semi)norm is nonarchimedean, since I will be using this in situations in which I need to consider more than one (semi)norm on the same additive group or ring.

It is likely that some of the proofs in `Mathlib.Analysis.Normed.Group.Ultra` can be refactored to use the proofs from this file, but please consider this being postponed to another PR, so that I can continue PRing the construction of C_p.

> Muddying the waters further, we also seem to have `NonarchimedeanHomClass` and various variants of it. @mariainesdff, since you seem to be the author of those classes and also of this PR, can you comment on how they relate to each other?

The relation between `IsNonarchimedean` and `NonarchimedeanHomClass` is similar for instance to that between `RingNorm` and `RingNormClass` - the first one is useful for writing down specific bundled maps, while the second is helpful for inheritance; I think both versions should be kept.

I can follow up and rephrase the proofs in this file I think. Given a SeminormHomClass, one can construct an in situation SeminormedAddCommGroup where the identified norm is defeq to the provided hom. And with IsNonarchimedean, get IsUltrametricDist. Then within the body of the proofs, the proof can use the lemmas in the Ultra file.

> > Muddying the waters further, we also seem to have `NonarchimedeanHomClass` and various variants of it. @mariainesdff, since you seem to be the author of those classes and also of this PR, can you comment on how they relate to each other?
> 
> The relation between `IsNonarchimedean` and `NonarchimedeanHomClass` is similar for instance to that between `RingNorm` and `RingNormClass` - the first one is useful for writing down specific bundled maps, while the second is helpful for inheritance; I think both versions should be kept.

We already have a bunch of such pairs, e.g. `NonarchAddGroupSeminorm` and `NonarchAddGroupSeminormClass` both exist. For consistency with this, shouldn't `IsNonarchimedean` be `NonarchimedeanHom`, and shouldn't `NonarchAddGroupSeminorm` derive from it?

I understand your viewpoint that you have a bunch of stuff already that you want to upstream, but this discussion needs to happen at some point. 

> I can follow up and rephrase the proofs in this file I think. Given a SeminormHomClass, one can construct an in situation SeminormedAddCommGroup where the identified norm is defeq to the provided hom. And with IsNonarchimedean, get IsUltrametricDist. Then within the body of the proofs, the proof can use the lemmas in the Ultra file.

This wouldn't be simple to do without sacrificing the fact that the material in `Normed/Group/Ultra` all works for both multiplicative and additive groups; Maria's approach doesn't look like it will play well with `@to_additive`.
I mean that the current file in question would import Ultra and not the other way around. And the defn of IsNonarchimedean would go back to Real/Basic.

> I can follow up and rephrase the proofs in this file I think. Given a SeminormHomClass, one can construct an in situation SeminormedAddCommGroup where the identified norm is defeq to the provided hom. And with IsNonarchimedean, get IsUltrametricDist. Then within the body of the proofs, the proof can use the lemmas in the Ultra file.

Thanks!

> We already have a bunch of such pairs, e.g. `NonarchAddGroupSeminorm` and `NonarchAddGroupSeminormClass` both exist. For consistency with this, shouldn't `IsNonarchimedean` be `NonarchimedeanHom`, and shouldn't `NonarchAddGroupSeminorm` derive from it?

The name `IsNonarchimedean` is more natural to me, but I could see why to change it to  `NonarchimedeanHom` (or, conversely, we could rename `NonarchimedeanHomClass` to `IsNonarchimedeanClass`).

As to the second question, yes, I think it would be natural for `NonarchAddGroupSeminorm`  to inherit from `IsNonarchimedean`.

> The name `IsNonarchimedean` is more natural to me, but I could see why to change it to `NonarchimedeanHom` (or, conversely, we could rename `NonarchimedeanHomClass` to `IsNonarchimedeanClass`).

I prefer the second option, since these maps don't seem to have a natural interpretation as morphisms in any particular category.
I am marking this as a WIP since it will likely be replaced by #17565.

> I am marking this as a WIP since it will likely be replaced by #17565.

That other PR is now closed because it's been merged into this one. So is this ready for review again?

> > I am marking this as a WIP since it will likely be replaced by #17565.
> 
> That other PR is now closed because it's been merged into this one. So is this ready for review again?

Yes.

I've pushed some changes as follows.
- I removed 3 of the 4 variations of the lemma constructing ultrametric normed groups from an unbundled norm-like function; everything seems to work fine with just the one, most general version.
- I added new lemmas in `Analysis/Normed/Group/Ultra` for the results about finset / multiset products, copying Maria's proofs pretty much verbatim, and replaced the proofs in Maria's file with references to those results.

I'm going to retract my comment about the normed _ring_ lemma, because it's probably not worth building the infrastructure of conversions between bundled / unbundled ring norms just for this one (very specific) lemma. 

There's still room for some cleanup in `Analysis/Normed/Group/Ultra`, to impose a bit more uniformity between related lemmas (and fill in the missing cases e.g. noncommutative List products); but I know Maria has a lot of stuff queued up behind this, so it's not fair to keep her waiting. I vote we go ahead and merge this PR now.

Maria: are you happy with this plan? If so, please remove the "awaiting author" tag, and I'll put it back on the maintainer-merge queue.

> Maria: are you happy with this plan? If so, please remove the "awaiting author" tag, and I'll put it back on the maintainer-merge queue.

Sounds good; thank you for your commits. I have removed the tag.
maintainer merge
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by loefflerd.
@pechersky is this good for you?
Agreed entirely with David Loeffler. LGTM.

Thanks!

bors merge

Can you please merge master and fix the error?

bors d+

:v: mariainesdff can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

Thanks!

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11442658481/job/31833495566)
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11442658481/job/31833496023)
I left some minor comments.
This looks fine to me.
This looks fine to me.
I left some minor comments.

I've left some comments. The general theme of my remarks is that I think we should complete the process of migrating the lemmas to `IsUltrametricDist`, and just refer to those here, using Yakov's trick of building an ad-hoc SeminormedGroup structure whose norm is the given one.
Use `Type*` throughout, please
Some people like to put definitions as early as possible, even if most of the results about the definition come later.

Thanks for reviewing! In this case, I do not see an advantage to having the definition in `Data/Real/Basic`. The reason I originally PR'd it there was to avoid creating a file containing only a definition.
I thought induction used `+ 1` by now. Please check if this is still needed (and if so, use the lemma rather than reproving it)
If you call it `IsNonarchimedean.add_le`, it would be eligible for dot notation, right?
Thanks, I will move this and the following lemmas to an `IsNonarchimedean` namespace.

I read this name as saying that `nsmul` is a morphism for which `IsNonarchimedean` is true. I think either `IsNonarchimedean.nsmul` or `nsmul_of_isNonarchimedean` would be better. (Or `nsmul_le` in either case?)

Similar comments for the results below
`le_of_not_le`?

```suggestion
  `t : Finset Î²`, we can always find `b : Î²`, belonging to `t` if `t` is nonempty, such that
```

```suggestion
    âˆƒ b : Î², (t.Nonempty â†’ b âˆˆ t) âˆ§ f (t.sum g) â‰¤ f (g b) := by
```

```suggestion
  multiset `s : Multiset Î²`, we can always find `b : Î²`, belonging to `s` if `s` is nonempty,
```
Same

```suggestion
          exact le_trans (hna _ _) (max_le hMa.le hM))
```
Is there any specific reason why you want `a` and `b`  explicit?
Not really; I have made them implicit.
Same question as above, about `n` and `a` being explicit.
ditto
Perhaps do you want to extract a primed lemma (or something) that assumes that `t` is nonempty, simplifying the result?
I have added that lemma.

```suggestion
  dist_comm x y := by simp only [â† map_inv_eq_map f (x / y), inv_div]
```

```suggestion
  âŸ¨fun x y z â†¦ by simpa only [hd, dist_eq_norm, AddGroupSeminormClass.toSeminormedAddGroup_norm_eq,
      â† sub_add_sub_cancel x y z] using hna _ _âŸ©
```
Why do we need this lemma, when we already have a version assuming the weaker typeclass `[AddGroup Î±]`?
@pechersky, could you comment of whether you need this lemma and the one from the following comment? (They both come from #17565 so I would like your opinion).
Again, why is this needed when we already have a version assuming `[AddGroupSeminormClass]` which is more general? Note that `AddGroupSeminormClass.isUltrametricDist hna hd` works for the proof.

The conclusion of the lemma feels strange, why not add nonemptiness as a hypothesis, rather than returning a conclusion which has nonemptiness buried inside it?

If this lemma is useful then I feel we should probably create a version of it for `SeminormedAddCommGroup`s, and apply that lemma here, rather than giving a proof for the current very specific context of "unbundled" norm functions. 

It also feels like the `obtain` statement in the middle of the proof should be a lemma in its own right, maybe `Finset.sup'_mem_image` (for functions into a linear order).
The next lemma `finset_image_add_of_nonempty` assumes nonemptiness.
Again, if this lemma is useful it should be made available in the more usual use case of bundled SeminoredAddCommGroups.
I need this as stated (I use it in a situation where there is not a bundled normed structure). In #17565 @pechersky mentioned that he was not able to generalize this proof.
Why is any "generalisation" required? It'd be the exact same proof, just packaged slightly differently. Let me have a quick shot at it.

Yes, I don't understand what the problem is here. Adding these lines to `Analysis/Normed/Group/Ultra.lean` works fine:
```lean
/--
Given a function `f : Î¹ â†’ M` and a finite set `t âŠ† Î¹`, we can always find `i : Î¹`, belonging to `t`
if `t` is nonempty, such that `â€–âˆ j in t, f jâ€– â‰¤ â€–f iâ€–`.
-/
@[to_additive "Given a function `f : Î¹ â†’ M` and a finite set `t âŠ† Î¹`, we can always find `i : Î¹`,
belonging to `t` if `t` is nonempty, such that `â€–âˆ‘ j in t, f jâ€– â‰¤ â€–f iâ€–`."]
theorem exists_norm_finset_prod_le (t : Finset Î¹) [Nonempty Î¹] {f : Î¹ â†’ M} :
    âˆƒ i : Î¹, (t.Nonempty â†’ i âˆˆ t) âˆ§ â€–âˆ j in t, f jâ€– â‰¤ â€–f iâ€– := by
  rcases t.eq_empty_or_nonempty with rfl | ht
  Â· simp
  have ht' : âˆ€ x âˆˆ t, âˆ€ y âˆˆ t, âˆƒ z âˆˆ t, â€–f zâ€– = max â€–f xâ€– â€–f yâ€– := by
    intros x hx y hy
    rcases le_total â€–f xâ€– â€–f yâ€– with h|h
    Â· exact âŸ¨y, hy, by simp [h]âŸ©
    Â· exact âŸ¨x, hx, by simp [h]âŸ©
  obtain âŸ¨x, hx, hx'âŸ© := Finset.sup'_mem (Î± := â„) ((â€–f Â·â€–) '' t) (by simpa [sup_eq_max] using ht') t
    ht (â€–f Â·â€–) (fun _ â†¦ Set.mem_image_of_mem _)
  refine âŸ¨x, fun _ â†¦ by simpa using hx, ?_âŸ©
  dsimp only at hx'
  rw [hx']
  exact ht.norm_prod_le_sup'_norm _

/--
Given a function `f : Î¹ â†’ M` and a multiset `t : Multiset Î¹`, we can always find `i : Î¹`, belonging
to `t` if `t` is nonempty, such that `â€–(s.map f).prodâ€– â‰¤ â€–f iâ€–`.
-/
@[to_additive "Given a function `f : Î¹ â†’ M` and a multiset `t : Multiset Î¹`, we can always find
`i : Î¹`, belonging to `t` if `t` is nonempty, such that `â€–(s.map f).sumâ€– â‰¤ â€–f iâ€–`."]
theorem exists_norm_multiset_prod_le (s : Multiset Î¹) [Nonempty Î¹] {f : Î¹ â†’ M} :
    âˆƒ i : Î¹, (s â‰  0 â†’ i âˆˆ s) âˆ§ â€–(s.map f).prodâ€– â‰¤ â€–f iâ€– := by
  inhabit Î¹
  induction s using Multiset.induction_on with
  | empty => simp
  | @cons a t hM =>
      obtain âŸ¨M, hMs, hMâŸ© := hM
      by_cases hMa : â€–f Mâ€– â‰¤ â€–f aâ€–
      Â· refine âŸ¨a, by simp, ?_âŸ©
        Â· rw [Multiset.map_cons, Multiset.prod_cons]
          exact le_trans (norm_mul_le_max _ _) (max_le (le_refl _) (le_trans hM hMa))
      Â· rw [not_le] at hMa
        rcases eq_or_ne t 0 with rfl|ht
        Â· exact âŸ¨a, by simp, by simpâŸ©
        Â· refine âŸ¨M, ?_, ?_âŸ©
          Â· simp [hMs ht]
          rw [Multiset.map_cons, Multiset.prod_cons]
          exact le_trans (norm_mul_le_max _ _) (max_le hMa.le hM)
```
I'm not 100% happy with the formulations, as I've already said â€“ the above is just a direct copy of what you had in your file. Can you explain why you chose this particular formulation in the case of an empty subset?

For `finset_image_add` there is also not an analogue in #17565 (instead, the proof inside the `IsNonarchimedean` file is modified). If you are looking into this, could you also have a look at this other lemma? Otherwise I do not see how to prove `add_pow_le` in the `[SeminormedRing R] [IsUltrametricDist R]` setting as you suggest below (and I do need that lemma for a proof in BGR).

The two lemmas in my last message are reformulations of both `finset_image_add` and `multiset_image_add`. More precisely, I gave the proofs of the product versions, but the `@[to_additive]` decorator creates from `exists_norm_finset_prod_le` a lemma `exists_norm_finset_sum_le` with statement
```lean
IsUltrametricDist.exists_norm_finset_sum_le.{u_1, u_2} {M : Type u_1} {Î¹ : Type u_2} [SeminormedAddCommGroup M]
  [IsUltrametricDist M] (t : Finset Î¹) [Nonempty Î¹] {f : Î¹ â†’ M} : âˆƒ i, (t.Nonempty â†’ i âˆˆ t) âˆ§ â€–âˆ‘ j âˆˆ t, f jâ€– â‰¤ â€–f iâ€–
```
which is exactly your `finset_image_add` written in terms of bundled norms.
Sorry, my browser had not updated, so I had not seen your reply before I wrote my comment.

As for the reason for the design:

In the construction of the spectral norm, I use the following lemma:
```lean
theorem isNonarchimedean_multiset_powerset_image_add {f : AlgebraNorm K L}
    (hf_na : IsNonarchimedean f) (s : Multiset L) (m : â„•) :
    âˆƒ t : Multiset L, card t = card s - m âˆ§ (âˆ€ x : L, x âˆˆ t â†’ x âˆˆ s) âˆ§
      f (Multiset.map Multiset.prod (powersetCard (card s - m) s)).sum â‰¤ f t.prod := by
```
The proof of this lemma uses `multiset_image_add`; here `m` could be equal to `card s`, in which case `t` is empty and I would not be able to apply that lemma with a nonemptiness hypothesis. 

`isNonarchimedean_multiset_powerset_image_add` does get applied in the case of `m = card s` ( see the proof of  [max_root_norm_eq_spectral_value](https://github.com/mariainesdff/LocalClassFieldTheory/blob/4efe76367694bdaa74610e9603c37d80eb772d62/LocalClassFieldTheory/FromMathlib/SpectralNorm.lean#L725)), and it allows me to not have to split the proof into the cases `m < card s` and `m = card s`.
Makes sense. Is it OK with you if I push to your PR branch to add the two lemmas above?
Yes, thank you!
focussing dot not needed, there's only one goal
... you can move the extra dot to here :-)
And again: if this lemma is useful we should formulate it for `[SeminormedRing R] [IsUltrametricDist R]` and refer to that here.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Data/Real/IsNonarchimedean): add lemmas

Yakov's spellings are slightly different, because the assumptions are given as `[Seminormed{Add}Group X] [IsUltrametricDist X]` rather than `[IsNonarchimedean (norm : X \to \RR)]`. I think we should try to standardize on one spelling rather than doing everything twice.

> 
> Yakov's spellings are slightly different, because the assumptions are given as `[Seminormed{Add}Group X] [IsUltrametricDist X]` rather than `[IsNonarchimedean (norm : X \to \RR)]`. I think we should try to standardize on one spelling rather than doing everything twice.

[IsUltrametricDist](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/MetricSpace/Ultra/Basic.html#IsUltrametricDist) is not enough for my purposes since it assumes that you have some canonical distance function (which in lemmas like [IsUltrametricDist.norm_add_le_max](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Normed/Group/Ultra.html#IsUltrametricDist.norm_add_le_max) would be the one induced by a bundled [SeminormedAddGroup](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/Normed/Group/Basic.html#SeminormedAddGroup) structure on your type).

However, I want to be able to make the statement that _a_ (semi)norm is nonarchimedean, since I will be using this in situations in which I need to consider more than one (semi)norm on the same additive group or ring.

It is likely that some of the proofs in `Mathlib.Analysis.Normed.Group.Ultra` can be refactored to use the proofs from this file, but please consider this being postponed to another PR, so that I can continue PRing the construction of C_p.

> Muddying the waters further, we also seem to have `NonarchimedeanHomClass` and various variants of it. @mariainesdff, since you seem to be the author of those classes and also of this PR, can you comment on how they relate to each other?

The relation between `IsNonarchimedean` and `NonarchimedeanHomClass` is similar for instance to that between `RingNorm` and `RingNormClass` - the first one is useful for writing down specific bundled maps, while the second is helpful for inheritance; I think both versions should be kept.

I can follow up and rephrase the proofs in this file I think. Given a SeminormHomClass, one can construct an in situation SeminormedAddCommGroup where the identified norm is defeq to the provided hom. And with IsNonarchimedean, get IsUltrametricDist. Then within the body of the proofs, the proof can use the lemmas in the Ultra file.

> > Muddying the waters further, we also seem to have `NonarchimedeanHomClass` and various variants of it. @mariainesdff, since you seem to be the author of those classes and also of this PR, can you comment on how they relate to each other?
> 
> The relation between `IsNonarchimedean` and `NonarchimedeanHomClass` is similar for instance to that between `RingNorm` and `RingNormClass` - the first one is useful for writing down specific bundled maps, while the second is helpful for inheritance; I think both versions should be kept.

We already have a bunch of such pairs, e.g. `NonarchAddGroupSeminorm` and `NonarchAddGroupSeminormClass` both exist. For consistency with this, shouldn't `IsNonarchimedean` be `NonarchimedeanHom`, and shouldn't `NonarchAddGroupSeminorm` derive from it?

I understand your viewpoint that you have a bunch of stuff already that you want to upstream, but this discussion needs to happen at some point. 

> I can follow up and rephrase the proofs in this file I think. Given a SeminormHomClass, one can construct an in situation SeminormedAddCommGroup where the identified norm is defeq to the provided hom. And with IsNonarchimedean, get IsUltrametricDist. Then within the body of the proofs, the proof can use the lemmas in the Ultra file.

This wouldn't be simple to do without sacrificing the fact that the material in `Normed/Group/Ultra` all works for both multiplicative and additive groups; Maria's approach doesn't look like it will play well with `@to_additive`.
I mean that the current file in question would import Ultra and not the other way around. And the defn of IsNonarchimedean would go back to Real/Basic.

> I can follow up and rephrase the proofs in this file I think. Given a SeminormHomClass, one can construct an in situation SeminormedAddCommGroup where the identified norm is defeq to the provided hom. And with IsNonarchimedean, get IsUltrametricDist. Then within the body of the proofs, the proof can use the lemmas in the Ultra file.

Thanks!

> We already have a bunch of such pairs, e.g. `NonarchAddGroupSeminorm` and `NonarchAddGroupSeminormClass` both exist. For consistency with this, shouldn't `IsNonarchimedean` be `NonarchimedeanHom`, and shouldn't `NonarchAddGroupSeminorm` derive from it?

The name `IsNonarchimedean` is more natural to me, but I could see why to change it to  `NonarchimedeanHom` (or, conversely, we could rename `NonarchimedeanHomClass` to `IsNonarchimedeanClass`).

As to the second question, yes, I think it would be natural for `NonarchAddGroupSeminorm`  to inherit from `IsNonarchimedean`.

> The name `IsNonarchimedean` is more natural to me, but I could see why to change it to `NonarchimedeanHom` (or, conversely, we could rename `NonarchimedeanHomClass` to `IsNonarchimedeanClass`).

I prefer the second option, since these maps don't seem to have a natural interpretation as morphisms in any particular category.

Yes.

I've left some comments. The general theme of my remarks is that I think we should complete the process of migrating the lemmas to `IsUltrametricDist`, and just refer to those here, using Yakov's trick of building an ad-hoc SeminormedGroup structure whose norm is the given one.

I've pushed some changes as follows.
- I removed 3 of the 4 variations of the lemma constructing ultrametric normed groups from an unbundled norm-like function; everything seems to work fine with just the one, most general version.
- I added new lemmas in `Analysis/Normed/Group/Ultra` for the results about finset / multiset products, copying Maria's proofs pretty much verbatim, and replaced the proofs in Maria's file with references to those results.

I'm going to retract my comment about the normed _ring_ lemma, because it's probably not worth building the infrastructure of conversions between bundled / unbundled ring norms just for this one (very specific) lemma. 

There's still room for some cleanup in `Analysis/Normed/Group/Ultra`, to impose a bit more uniformity between related lemmas (and fill in the missing cases e.g. noncommutative List products); but I know Maria has a lot of stuff queued up behind this, so it's not fair to keep her waiting. I vote we go ahead and merge this PR now.
